text: <@U01KXU8UNRX>, Di Cook was wondering on the Forwards Slack if anyone had tabulated bug fixes by people. I know that the data you have is anonymized, but maybe it is possible find the top 30 people that have contributed to bugs in the last 3 years and cross-check them against actual bug reports to identify these people? It would be helpful to know who is actively triaging bugs other than R Core developers, so that we can engage with them in our initiatives.

elements.text: , Di Cook was wondering on the Forwards Slack if anyone had tabulated bug fixes by people. I know that the data you have is anonymized, but maybe it is possible find the top 30 people that have contributed to bugs in the last 3 years and cross-check them against actual bug reports to identify these people? It would be helpful to know who is actively triaging bugs other than R Core developers, so that we can engage with them in our initiatives.

text: It is easy to find people who has been commenting on bugs they haven't opened, will add that on the analysis. Currently I didn't focused on user behavior much, but maybe it would be interesting to see who have provided more attachments/patches. It is relatively easy to identify users checking where they commented or opened bugs, for one or two I've done that manually, for 30 is doable (also the API could be used for that via bugRzilla).
